Poland

501 legendary date of foundation of Polish Principality 964 reign of first documented prince (Mieszko I) 25 Dec 1024 Polish Kingdom 1031 Polish Principality 25 Dec 1076 Polish Kingdom Jun 1079 Polish Principality 28 Oct 1138 divisions into several principalities, until 1180 under nominal coordination by one of the princes, styled Senior Polish Prince 26 Jun 1295 - 8 Feb 1296 Przemysl II styled Polish King 20 Jan 1320 all Poland, except for Silesia, reunited into Polish Kingdom 1370 kingship becomes elective, but de facto the Diet chooses the kings in hereditary order until 1572 4 Jul 1569 Accord of Lublin, colloquially known as "Union of Lublin," joining Poland and Lithuania officially, but not constitutionally, into United Commonwealth of the Two Nations, in short, The Commonwealth 6 Jul 1572 last hereditary Polish king dies; power to elect the king moves from the Diet to the whole nobility; election as Polish king and grand prince of Lithuania is carried out jointly, but conduct of interregnum is separate 3 May 1791 constitution gives formal sanction to the union with Lithuania 7 Jan 1795 incorporated into Russia 9 Jul 1807 Duchy of Warsaw 20 Jun 1815 - 5 Nov 1916 Polish Kingdom, in (nominally personal, actually subordinate) union with Russia, established by the Congress of Vienna (thus often referred to by historians as Congress Poland) 25 Jan 1831 - 26 Sep 1831 "First Insurrection" 22 Jan 1863 - Apr 1865 "Second Insurrection" 14 Jan 1917 Polish Kingdom 6 Nov 1918 Polish State 22 Nov 1918 Polish Republic 1 Sep 1939 German invasion 17 Sep 1939 Soviet invasion 6 Oct 1939 last Polish troops capitulate; ¹Under the elective kingship, a king assumed office upon his coronation at the Coronation Diet. The record also includes the date of proclamation of the election at the Election Diet. From 6 Jan 1573, during vacancies in the elective kingship the primate of Poland ex officio (occasionally another prelate, in emergency situations) headed the state with the style Interrex. In the United Commonwealth of Two Nations, the Polish king also had the style of Grand Prince of Lithuania, and the two countries were governed together and were represented on the Diets. Although de jure the Polish Interrex only dealt with Poland during a vacancy in the kingship (the Lithuanian Council of State dealing with Lithuania), this is de facto a spurious distinction. The full style of Polish kings from 1573 was Dei Gratiae Rex Poloniae, Magnus Dux Lituaniae, Russiae, Prussiae, Masoviae, Samogithiae, Kiioviae, Volhyniae, Podoliae, Podlachiae, Livoniae, Smolensciae, Severiae, Czernichoviaeque (official Latin style) or Z Bozej laski Król Polski, Wielki Ksiaze Litewski, Ruski, Pruski, Mazowiecki, Zmudzki, Kijowski, Wolynski, Podolski, Podlaski, Inflancki, Smolenski, Siewierski i Czernihowski (Polish) ("By the Grace of God, King of Poland, Grand Duke of Lithuania, Russia, Prussia, Mazovia, Samogitia, Kiev, Volhynia, Podolia, Podlachia, Livonia, Smolensk, Severia and Chernigov").

²The Polish government in exile lost the diplomatic recognition of the Western Allies on 5 Jul 1945.

¹The immediate agent of French authority (apparently without a specific style) was Jean-Andoche Junot (b. 1771 - d. 1813), titled duc d'Abrantès (duque de Abrantes).

²The style of the ruler was:

(a) 1499 - 16 Dec 1815, 13 May 1825 - 10 Sep 1836, 10 Feb 1842 - 5 Oct 1910: Por graça de Deus, Rei/Rainha de Portugal e dos Algarves de aquém e de além-mar em África, Senhor/Senhora de Guiné e da Conquista, Navegação e Comércio da Etiópia, Arábia, Pérsia, e da Índia ("By the grace of God, King/Queen of Portugal and the Algarves, of either side of the sea in Africa, Lord/Lady of Guinea and of the Conquest, Navigation, and Commerce of Ethiopia, Arabia, Persia, and India");

(b) 16 Dec 1815 - 26 Feb 1821, 2 Jun 1823 - 13 May 1825: Por graça de Deus, Rei/Rainha do Reino Unido de Portugal, e do Brasil, e Algarves de aquém e de além mar em África, Senhor/Senhora de Guiné e da Conquista, Navegação e Comércio da Etiópia, Arábia, Pérsia, e da Índia;

(c) 26 Feb 1821 - 2 Jun 1823: Por graça de Deus e pela constituição da monarquia, Rei do Reino-Unido de Portugal, Brasil e Algarve de aquém e de além-mar em África, Senhor de Guiné e da Conquista, Navegação e Comércio da Etiópia, Arábia, Pérsia, e da Índia;

(d) 10 Sep 1836 - 10 Feb 1842: Por graça de Deus e pela constituição da monarquia, Rei/Rainha de Portugal e Algarves de aquém e de além-mar em África, Senhor/Senhora de Guiné e da Conquista, Navegação e Comércio da Etiópia, Arábia, Pérsia, e da Índia.

³The heir apparent, Luís Filipe (b. 1887 - d. 1908), assassinated with Carlos I on 1 Feb 1908, outlived Carlos I by minutes, but was neither proclaimed nor recorded as king.
